The second premise is a negation of the antecedent: "The shirt was not cotton", which can be represented as "¬C".

The conclusion is a negation of the consequent: "The pants were not denim", which can be represented as "¬D".

This would not contradict the first premise, as the premise only states that if the shirt is cotton, then the pants are denim, but it doesn't say anything about what happens when the shirt is not cotton.
